title: Stored XSS Vulnerability
content:
Hi there,
I found a stored xss @ https://core.trac.wordpress.org/
Steps:
Go to https://core.trac.wordpress.org/ and login. (open new private window and login with another account)
Go to https://core.trac.wordpress.org/newticket and set a summary and description.
Select a Workflow Keyword and click manual. Paste the payload: "><svg/onload=alert(document.domain)>
Click enter button and click Create Ticket button. Now, you will see xss alert. Copy the url and go to private window. Go to url and you will see xss alert.
PoC: https://youtu.be/Nyt1op_73vs
Impact
Stealing cookies
steps: Go to https://core.trac.wordpress.org/ and login (use a private window with a different account).
Navigate to https://core.trac.wordpress.org/newticket and fill in the summary and description fields.
Select a Workflow Keyword, choose 'manual', and paste the payload: "><svg/onload=alert(document.domain)>".
Click 'Create Ticket' to trigger the XSS alert. Copy the URL and open it in another private window to confirm the vulnerability.
vuln_description: A stored XSS vulnerability exists in the WordPress Trac system, allowing an attacker to inject malicious JavaScript code into a ticket. When another user views the ticket, the script executes, potentially leading to cookie theft or other malicious actions.
reason: The vulnerability involves a straightforward injection of a common XSS payload into a ticket field. The steps are simple and do not require complex interactions or understanding of subtle application behaviors. The payload used is a well-known XSS vector.

injection_metadata.reasoning: The stored XSS vulnerability involves injecting a payload into the ticket creation form (summary/description parameters), which is a standard user workflow. The methodology would log these parameters during regular navigation. The payload "<svg/onload=alert(document.domain)> is a simple context-aware XSS payload without custom filter bypasses. The trigger occurs when viewing the ticket via normal navigation (same channel), meeting the 'simple payload' criteria where injection and execution are within the same application flow.

authnz_metadata.reason: The stored XSS vulnerability involves injecting malicious JavaScript into a ticket's summary or description, which is then executed when another user views the ticket. This does not directly involve authentication or authorization bypass, but rather a failure in input sanitization leading to client-side code execution. The methodology described focuses on testing authentication and authorization boundaries by swapping user sessions and resource IDs, which is not applicable here as the vulnerability does not rely on crossing such boundaries.
